intro: Guatteria xalapensis, commonly known as the Mexican persimmon, is a species of flowering plant in the family Lauraceae. It is native to Mexico and parts of Central America, typically found in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant is characterized by its evergreen leaves, which are glossy and leathery in texture. It produces small, fragrant flowers that are usually white or pale yellow, followed by edible, orange-colored berries. The fruit is often consumed raw or used in local culinary traditions.
